parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across two actions involving acoustically reflective materials on fishing gear, the evidence differs in strength and outcomes.
[Statement 2]: Two studies found no benefits for attaching acoustically reflective objects to fishing gear.
[Statement 3]: Metallic bead chains attached to nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 4]: Acrylic beads attached near hooks did not reduce sperm whale depredation on catches.
[Statement 5]: Five studies reported mixed but partly positive results for using acoustically reflective materials in the fishing gear itself.
[Statement 6]: Two of three controlled studies found fewer harbour porpoise entanglements in nets made with iron-oxide or barium sulfate.
[Statement 7]: One study found that nets made with barium sulfate did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 8]: Behavioural studies showed that porpoises approached nets made with barium sulfate and conventional nets in a similar way.
[Statement 9]: Porpoises produced fewer echolocation clicks at nets made with barium sulfate.
[Statement 10]: Overall echolocation activity from porpoises was similar at both barium sulfate nets and conventional net types.

key: _gpt-5__How does the evidence for using acoustically reflective materials on fishing gear compare to attaching acoustically reflective objects for reducing marine mammal entanglement?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies reported behavioural changes in marine mammals associated with acoustic deterrent devices.
[Statement 2]: When acoustic deterrent devices were placed on fishing gear, marine mammals approached fishing nets or lines less closely.
[Statement 3]: Marine mammals had fewer encounters or interactions with nets when acoustic deterrent devices were placed on fishing gear.
[Statement 4]: When acoustic deterrent devices were placed on fishing gear, there was reduced activity and sightings of marine mammals in surrounding areas.
[Statement 5]: Dolphins avoided a boat more frequently when acoustic deterrent devices were deployed alongside the boat.
[Statement 6]: Killer whales were recorded further from a fishing vessel during the use of acoustic deterrent devices.
[Statement 7]: The distance of killer whales from a fishing vessel decreased after the whales' first exposure to an acoustic deterrent device.
[Statement 8]: When acoustic deterrent devices were used from vessels, dolphins showed reduced surfacing, echolocation, and time spent foraging or socializing.
[Statement 9]: The numbers or activity of seals, porpoises, and dolphins were reduced near moored acoustic deterrent devices.
[Statement 10]: The echolocation activity of harbour porpoises was reduced by acoustic deterrent devices.
[Statement 11]: Harbour porpoises had an increasing probability of making close approaches to acoustic deterrent devices over a period of 10–11 days.
[Statement 12]: Acoustic deterrent devices caused reductions in seal numbers upstream of the devices without reducing overall seal numbers.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across the North Atlantic and North Sea, deploying acoustic devices (pingers) on fishing nets and lines has repeatedly reduced cetacean entanglements or collisions.
[Statement 2]: The use of acoustic devices (pingers) has resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises and other small cetaceans.
[Statement 3]: A controlled study in the North Atlantic found that nets with a complete set of pingers had fewer harbour porpoise entanglements than nets with an incomplete set.
[Statement 4]: A replicated, controlled study spanning the North Sea and Baltic Sea showed reductions in harbour porpoise entanglement in one fishing area but not in the other.
[Statement 5]: Using acoustically reflective net materials, such as iron-oxide or barium sulfate, has reduced harbour porpoise entanglements in the North Sea.
[Statement 6]: Another study found that barium-sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.

[Statement 1]: Approximately three-quarters of Antillean manatees released after captive rearing were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 2]: Approximately two-thirds of Florida manatees released after captive rearing were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 3]: Some individual manatees released after captive rearing survived for more than seven years.
[Statement 4]: Most captive-reared Antillean manatees released back into the wild reproduced.
[Statement 5]: Poor outcomes were reported for some captive-reared West Indian and Antillean manatee calves.
[Statement 6]: The poor outcomes for some captive-reared manatee calves included deaths before or after release.
[Statement 7]: The poor outcomes for some captive-reared manatee calves included returns to captivity.
[Statement 8]: The poor outcomes for some captive-reared manatee calves included survival only with supplemental feeding.
[Statement 9]: Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 10]: Two of fourteen Florida manatees born in captivity and released into the wild survived for at least one year without further intervention.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: One study reported fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales when cage or chain devices were used on hooks.
[Statement 2]: Two studies found that net sleeves or cage/chain devices on hooks reduced damage to fish catches by sperm whales, killer whales and toothed whales.
[Statement 3]: Two other studies found that ‘umbrella’ or ‘spider’ devices did not reduce predation or damage by sperm whales or toothed whales.
[Statement 4]: One controlled study found streamer-based catch protection on lines reduced Indo-Pacific bottlenose and spinner dolphin bait predation, but only during the first two trials.
[Statement 5]: Two controlled studies found that adding steel rods to lobster pots or metal frames to pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey and harbour seals entering or becoming trapped.
[Statement 6]: Two controlled studies reported that installing wire grids or steel bars on trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting or other access-preventing modifications, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 7]: One controlled study showed that securing crab pot doors with a bungee cord reduced common bottlenose dolphin interactions.
[Statement 8]: One controlled study found that wire grids on trap-nets, with strengthened netting, resulted in higher catches of undamaged salmon but not whitefish.
[Statement 9]: The higher catches of undamaged salmon were likely due to reduced seal predation.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Using bubble curtains or screens is a documented intervention to dampen underwater noise during pile driving.
[Statement 2]: A site comparison study in the North Sea reported smaller decreases in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km at sites using bubble curtains or screens compared to sites without these measures.
[Statement 3]: Reducing hammer energy during pile driving is listed as an intervention.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of reducing hammer energy during pile driving.
[Statement 5]: Using ‘soft start’ procedures to deter mammals is a documented intervention.
[Statement 6]: Across three studies in the UK, Gabon and Australia, cetaceans more often avoided or moved away during soft starts.
[Statement 7]: During soft start procedures, short-finned pilot whales initially moved away but remained within 900 meters.
[Statement 8]: During soft start procedures, migrating humpback whales slowed down but did not significantly alter their course.
[Statement 9]: Acoustic deterrent devices are a reported intervention to keep mammals away from noisy areas.
[Statement 10]: Four studies in Germany, Denmark and Iceland found that acoustic deterrent devices reduced harbour porpoise activity or sightings at distances of 1–18 km.
[Statement 11]: In response to acoustic deterrent devices, minke whales were observed moving away with increased speed and straighter paths.
[Statement 12]: Delaying or ceasing operations when mammals are detected within a specified zone is a listed intervention.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of delaying or ceasing operations when mammals are detected within a specified zone.
[Statement 14]: Modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance is a listed intervention.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance.
[Statement 16]: Limiting, ceasing or prohibiting the use of sonars is a listed intervention.
[Statement 17]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of limiting, ceasing or prohibiting the use of sonars on subtidal benthic invertebrates.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Six studies assessed modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals.
[Statement 2]: The studies on modifying fishing pots and traps were conducted across the North Sea, Indian River Lagoon, Gulf of Finland, Bothnian Sea, Indian Ocean, and Baltic Sea.
[Statement 3]: Two controlled studies found that using steel rods or metal frames on pots reduced Australian sea lion pup entries.
[Statement 4]: Two controlled studies found that using steel rods or metal frames on pots reduced grey and harbour seal trapping.
[Statement 5]: Four controlled studies reported reduced seal damage to salmon catches.
[Statement 6]: One of two tested crab-pot door methods resulted in reduced bottlenose dolphin interactions.
[Statement 7]: Higher catches of undamaged salmon were reported with the use of wire grids and strengthened netting.
[Statement 8]: Seven studies evaluated installing exclusion or escape devices on fishing nets in the Indian Ocean, Tasman Sea, and South Atlantic.
[Statement 9]: Two studies reported that less than one-third of bottlenose dolphins exited trawl escape hatches alive.
[Statement 10]: Two studies reported fewer fur seal deaths when larger escape openings were used on fishing nets.
[Statement 11]: Five studies found that installing exclusion or escape devices on nets reduced entanglements of Antarctic fur seals and bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 12]: Reductions in entanglements were observed on three of four vessels after the installation of an exclusion or escape device.
[Statement 13]: Fewer fur seal entanglements occurred after an escape panel was enlarged or relocated.

parts.text:

[Statement 4]: Minke whales moved away, swam faster, and swam more directly when an acoustic device was deployed from a boat.

[Statement 7]: In the presence of acoustic devices on vessels, humpback and snubfin dolphins showed reduced surfacing, echolocation, and time spent foraging or socializing.
[Statement 8]: Acoustic devices did not reduce Risso’s dolphin predation on squid catches.

[Statement 1]: Four studies documented behavioral effects of introducing and enforcing regulations for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours.
[Statement 2]: The studies on mammal watching tours were conducted across sites in the North Atlantic (Azores), Cananéia estuary (Brazil), South Pacific (Australia), and Bass Strait (Australia).
[Statement 3]: When whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods changed behaviors or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
[Statement 4]: Changes in behavior for sperm whales and humpback whales included swimming speed and aerial displays.
[Statement 5]: The direction of movement and diving patterns of sperm whales and humpback whales did not differ when whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations versus when the regulations were not followed.
[Statement 6]: In the Cananéia estuary, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviors such as moving away, diving, or groups separating when tour boats complied with approach regulations.
[Statement 7]: In the Bass Strait, more seals remained on shore when boats approached a seal colony to 75 meters than when boats approached to 25 meters.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of developing and implementing general vessel-operation regulations around mammals.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of introducing permits or licences for mammal watching tours.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Five of six studies on acoustic devices on fishing gear reported reduced damage to fish catches and/or nets by dolphins and seals.
[Statement 2]: One study on acoustic devices on fishing gear found no reduction in swordfish catch damage by California sea lions.
[Statement 3]: One randomized, controlled study on acoustic devices on vessels reported no reduction in predation of squid catches by Risso’s dolphins when devices of two types were used.
[Statement 4]: One randomized, controlled study on acoustic devices on moorings reported a reduction in the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.

[Statement 1]: In UK waters, a greater proportion of cetaceans avoided or moved away from vessels during ‘soft start’ procedures with seismic airguns compared to when airguns were not firing.
[Statement 2]: In the South Atlantic, a pod of short-finned whales initially moved away from a vessel during a 'soft start' procedure with seismic airguns but remained within 900 meters of the vessel.
[Statement 3]: In the South Pacific, migrating humpback whales slowed the whales' speed toward a vessel using 'soft start' procedures with seismic airguns without significantly altering the whales' course.
[Statement 4]: A study in the North Sea found that using bubble curtains or screens during pile driving led to smaller decreases in harbour porpoise detections within 15 km compared to sites without bubble curtains or screens.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of delaying or ceasing operations when marine mammals are detected within an exclusion zone.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of using acoustic devices at renewable energy sites.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of reducing hammer energy during pile driving.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of modifying vessels to reduce noise disturbance.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Diverting shipping routes is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 2]: Modifying vessels to reduce the risk of physical injury to mammals is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 3]: Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 4]: Two studies reported that speed limits in key habitats were associated with fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths from collisions.
[Statement 5]: Two studies reported that speed limits in key habitats were associated with fewer manatee deaths when limits were enforced system-wide.
[Statement 6]: Using remote tools to detect mammals so vessels can alter course or speed is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 7]: Using observers on board vessels to detect mammals and adjust course or speed is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 8]: Using real-time automated on-board detection tools to allow course or speed changes is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 9]: Developing and implementing regulations for operating vessels around mammals is an identified action to reduce the risk of lethal vessel collisions with large whales.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of diverting shipping routes.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of modifying vessels.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of remote detection tools.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of using observers on board vessels.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of real-time automated tools.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the effects of regulations for operating vessels around mammals.

_gpt-5__What are the documented population-level outcomes of legally protecting marine mammals and their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A Mediterranean monk seal population increased over eight years after the islands the seals inhabited were legally protected.
[Statement 2]: A bottlenose dolphin population in the North Sea was estimated to be a similar size before and after part of the dolphin population's range was protected.
[Statement 3]: Hector’s dolphin survival rate was higher after a coastal area was legally protected than before protection.
[Statement 4]: In the Port River estuary, a similar number of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings were recorded after protection compared to before protection.
[Statement 5]: In the Port River estuary, the number of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings caused by humans decreased after protection.
[Statement 6]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the population-level effects of legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found that directly evaluated the population-level effects of establishing a network of protected areas for marine and freshwater mammals.
[Statement 8]: After hunting was prohibited, abundance increased for harbour seals over 7–30 years in multiple regions.
[Statement 9]: After hunting was prohibited, abundance increased for humpback whales over 7–30 years in multiple regions.
[Statement 10]: Numbers of mature male sperm whales did not differ significantly before or 31 years after the prohibition of hunting.
[Statement 11]: A review reported significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during 7–21 years after legislation to prohibit hunting.
[Statement 12]: Harbour porpoise activity increased at a stony reef after fishing was prohibited and the reef was restored with boulders.

[Statement 1]: Hand-rearing orphaned or abandoned young has yielded documented post-release survival in individual gray whale, Steller sea lion, and bottlenose dolphin calves over monitoring periods of days to months.
[Statement 2]: Approximately three-quarters of released hand-reared Antillean manatees are known to survive at least one year.
[Statement 3]: Approximately two-thirds of released hand-reared Florida manatees are known to survive at least one year.
[Statement 4]: Some captive-reared manatees reproduced after being released.
[Statement 5]: The survival of released Pacific harbour seal pups that were hand-reared was similar to that of wild pups.
[Statement 6]: Some captive-reared individuals died before or after release, were returned to captivity, or survived only with supplemental feeding.
[Statement 7]: Released harbour seal pups that were hand-reared travelled greater distances and farther from the release site than wild pups.
[Statement 8]: Rehabilitating and releasing injured, sick, or weak marine mammals resulted in 10–100% survival during monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years across multiple species and locations.
[Statement 9]: More than a quarter of rehabilitated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced after being released.
[Statement 10]: The behaviour of some rehabilitated harbour porpoises and harbour seals was similar to that of wild animals.
[Statement 11]: At least a quarter of California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning died or were euthanized.
[Statement 12]: Released California sea lions treated for toxic algae poisoning showed altered movements, reduced time diving or hauled out, and shorter, shallower dives compared to wild individuals of the same species.
[Statement 13]: Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped marine mammals yielded 17–100% survival over three weeks to three years in multiple dolphin, whale, and seal species.
[Statement 14]: Reproduction was documented in a rescued bottlenose dolphin after release.
[Statement 15]: More than a quarter of rescued and released Hawaiian monk seals survived and reproduced when the process was combined with at least seven other survival-enhancing interventions.
[Statement 16]: Releasing captive-bred manatees led to the survival of two of three Antillean manatees for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 17]: Releasing captive-bred manatees led to the survival of two of 14 Florida manatees for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 18]: No studies were found evaluating outcomes of rehabilitating and releasing marine mammals following oil spills.
